fields.description:
Create a scheduled trigger, for example 0 0 6-21 ? * * and save the changes.

Go click around Bamboo and then return the the trigger setting view. The field is not displayed as a nice summary but only the "pencil" is visible.  Clicking the pencil, you are also not returned to the cron field (which has been set), but left with the default radio button of "daily" view.

Ideally, when cron is set as a trigger, provide a summary in the trigger setting view either as the string itself, or elegantly, an text description.

This is a UI bug, and does not effect functionality of the scheduling.
fields.summary: Cron string is not displayed in Trigger Setting view once set

fields.summary: Bamboo 5.6.0 fails to start

fields.description:
Sometimes bamboo detects errors, and reports them in nice yellow boxes.

Clicking on "View error details" seems to be intended to show more about the error, however at least with my browser the window shows just garbage. See the screenshots.

I saved the garbage using firefox, and it gets reported as:
{noformat}
$ file response.txt
response.txt: gzip compressed data, from Unix
{noformat}

Running this through gunzip, producing response.txt.2:
{noformat}
$ file response.txt.2
response.txt.2: gzip compressed data, from FAT filesystem (MS-DOS, OS/2, NT)
{noformat}

... again doing that produces some HTML, with the expected error details.


(Note: affects-version is 5.6-OD-01-0070, which cannot be selected from the selector ...)

Browser: Build identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:34.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/34.0

*EDIT*: This seems to be affecting Chrome and Internet Explorer for the latest Bamboo OnDemand, Firefox is showing the error correctly.
fields.summary: "View error details" opens new window with "garbage"

fields.summary: Cannot install Bamboo 5.6.0 using external database

fields.description: I noticed that on Bamboo when I view it the Bamboo icon which is highlighted on the attached image is truncated so the Bamboo doesn't display correctly. Not a major thing by any means but annoying once you noticed it.
fields.summary: Truncation of Bamboo Image on Bamboo UI

fields.description:
On SBAC, CBAC and JBAC, I have been able to reproduce this problem where a linked Stash-type repository will cause an error message to be shown in the repositories tab of a plan configuration.

It's worth pointing out that when the plan runs, the repositories showing this error do work as expected, repository functionality appears to be perfectly fine.

Please watch the following for repro steps:
!bamboo.gif!

Tested on 5.6-m4
fields.summary: Plan Config's repositories tab shows "Please provide a serverKey" for Stash repo

fields.description:
Embedding special characters in the git password can cause Bamboo to incorrectly parse the URL required for git. The string:

https://USER:p@ssword@bitbucket.org/PATH/info/refs

is actually being split at the first @, rather than the second. giving "ssword"  as the password for the user and so failing with 404.

Ideally we would validate for only one @, or split the string differently.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to connect with special characters in password field

fields.description: {color:red}colored text{color}It's currently not possible to automatically build pull-requests when they are created from a fork.
fields.summary: Automatic build pull-requests from fork

fields.description:
We are currently seeing an issue with AWS Elastic Instances on OnDemand where Elastic Instances are terminating, but the Agent isn't being released and so we're hitting the license cap and eventually unable to build anything.

When this happens, Bamboo still spins up new AWS instances, but the Agent throws an exception during initialisation and then just stops. The instance then sits on AWS until it times out and naturally terminates. There's no way to kill the Agents once the EC2 instance has terminated, and so no way to release the license from the allocation pool.
fields.summary: Agents running on Elastic Instances aren't being unregistered when the Instance is terminated

fields.description:
I have bamboo and JIRA linked to each other. Bamboo isn't configured to require auth to view builds, but JIRA is (default settings)

If I have a plan branch with an issue in it (eg 'TEST-5'), and I'm not logged into Bamboo, then clicking on the link from the branch summary page (http://localhost:6990/bamboo/browse/TEST-TEST10/ - see screenshot), leads to an bamboo error page saying that: "An unexpected error has occurred
Unable to find application link for the supplied parameters."

If I'm logged into bamboo then this works fine; it doesn't matter if I'm logged into JIRA or not.

In the screenshot, clicking on a linked issue correctly takes me to JIRA - its only the branch link that doesn't work.

There are no errors in either the bamboo or JIRA logs when this happens.
fields.summary: Error when clicking to JIRA issue from bamboo and not logged in

fields.description:
When stash (v3.1.3), bamboo (v5.6.0) and JIRA are linked, with automatic branch creation configured, bamboo doesn't link issues mentioned in commit messages that are pushed with the branch creation.

To reproduce:

1. Create a JIRA issue (TEST-1)
2. Create a new repository in stash. Make sure it has a file in it (so that master exists)
3. Create a bamboo build plan for the new repo, with automatic branch creation configured
4. in the new repo, run:
  * git checkout -b TEST-1-branch
  * echo "TEST" > test.txt
  * git add test.txt; git commit -m 'TEST-1 message' test.txt
  * git push --all
5. Wait for bamboo to pick up the change and run a build

In Stash, the commit is linked to TEST-1 (and the commit and branch show up in JIRA).

However, in Bamboo the 'issues' tab (http://localhost:6990/bamboo/browse/TEST-TEST10/issues) doesn't show any linked issues, and JIRA doesn't show a build status.

A subsequent checkin (ie "echo X > test.txt; git commit -m 'TEST-1 msg' test.txt; git push") causes this to work as expected, and the link then shows up.
fields.summary: Commit pushed at branch creation time doesn't link to issue

fields.description:
With stash/bamboo applications links configured, and bamboo use automatic branch creation, the following steps fail:

1. Create a new branch, 'test'
2. Bamboo creates a plan for the 'test' branch, and builds it
3. Delete the 'test' branch in stash
4. Bamboo disables the test branch plan
5. Create a branch called 'test' in stash again

Expected: 'test' branch is re-enabled
Actual: Bamboo logs have an exception:

2014-07-29 22:53:04,976 INFO [http-6990-31] [AccessLogFilter] 10.1.1.250 POST http://pear.home:6990/bamboo/rest/remote-event-consumer/latest/events/stash-branch-created-remote-event 76458kb
2014-07-29 22:53:05,006 ERROR [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-7] [AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher] There was an exception thrown trying to dispatch event 'com.atlassian.stash.pl
ugin.remote.event.StashBranchCreatedRemoteEvent@303bcb6b[branchName=test1,repositoryProject=TEST,repositorySlug=test,committer=admin,sourceId=1041209f-b842-3d23-b1ed-0c22aaa2e1ba,sourceUrl=h
ttp://pear.home:7990/stash]' from the invoker 'SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker{method=public void com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.stash.events.BranchCreatedEventListener.onCreateRepository

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Due to limitations in Stash, Bamboo has to store the ssh key for a linked repository against an individual user when the repository is first created/saved. When a Bamboo user who didn't create/save the linked repo looks at it, Bamboo can't find the SSH key in their profile and will display the red banner error message below:
{noformat}
Click Save repository at the bottom of this screen to re-establish access to this repository.
{noformat}

!stasherror 2014-07-28 14-55-01.jpg|thumbnail!

This message is harmless. If this second user then saves the repository to get rid of the red error message, the new key will be saved against that second user and the original user will now see the red error message.  Users may find themselves going round in circles (and generating an unnecessary number of keys in their Stash accounts along the way).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect your Bitbucket Server to your Bamboo instance using AppLinks
# Add a "Linked Repository"
# Connect as a second user and view this "Linked Repository" and the message will be displayed

h3. Expected Results

The intent of this message is to show the administrator the checkout of a "Linked Repository" is failing due to a missing SSH key (i.e. the SSH key had been removed from the Stash by mistake).

Of course, with the limitation of adding the SSH key to the user who created the repo in Stash, showing the message to people who didn't save the repository does not help.

Therefore, the message should be shown only if they key was removed from the profile of the person who created the repo.

Conversely, having Bamboo using access keys as opposed to personal keys would be a better solution.

h3. Actual Results

The  red banner is shown every time.
 
h3.Workaround

The repository still continues to work, doing its change detection and clones/fetches using the correct user/key combination as when another Bamboo user saves the repo, the SSH keys will be saved to his Stash account's profile. Therefore this message is harmless and more an annoyance for the Bamboo users and should be fixed.
fields.summary: Stash Repository frequently reports "Access Removed" messages when there is no issue

fields.description:
Consider working on a product which has numerous officially supported releases developed over a span of several years. From a business perspective, support is offered until the release reaches EOL.  Each official release and subsequent service pack may have a branch in the VCS.  Customers may pay for patching and old unsupported release, so you should have to capacity to maintain and build them.

At some point during the lifecycle of a product you're going to upgrade the tooling, underlying frameworks and thus the build process.  This poses a problem.

If release v1 of the product was built using Visual Studio 2010 and MSBuild v4.0, then all subsequent maintenance to that branch should be built with Visual Studio 2010 and MSBuild v4.0. 

If release v10 of the product was built using Visual Studio 2013 and MSBuild v12.0, then all subsequent maintenance to that branch should be built with Visual Studio 2013 and MSBuild v12.0.  

In the case of Visual C++, applications built in Visual Studio 2010 uses the Visual C++ 2010 runtime, and those built with Visual Studio 2013 uses the Visual C++ 2013 runtime.  It may not be feasible to upgrade the runtime for v1.0 of the product, since this requires changes to installers etc. Since there may be regressions, the testing effort may be stupendous.   

The same challenges applies when developing commercial off-the-shelf applications in Java, Ruby, Python, C/C++, Node.js etc. 

Lets consider that numerous teams distributed different locales are maintaining the product. Feature branches are heavily used as to not disrupt other teams. You may end with tens if not hundreds of feature, release and hot fix branches.

So to reduce the cost of maintenance, you'd like Bamboo to automatically manage build plans for branches.  In essence, a developer creates a feature branch and bamboo will maintain the build plan. After all, the build process is almost identical for every VCS branch, except perhaps for the version of the tools being used and how its invoked. 

It seems that for Bamboo to effectively manage and build branch specific plans, that it must support the capacity to version some part of the plan configuration to allow for differences between branches.  For example, when you developed release v1, you had a job named "Build" which used MSBuild 4.0 (32bit) to build the Visual Studio solution. For v10, that changes to MSBuild 12.0 (32bit). 

It is thus feasible to request that Bamboo store the plan and its corresponding stages, jobs and tasks in a file that can be versioned with the source.  Upon a build, Bamboo can read this information, detect the appropriate agents and then execute the build. TFS already supports that today.

Some plan configurations, such as additional requirements, the location of artifacts, tool output (NCover, NUnit), build hung properties, can be versioned too, since they may change from VCS branch to VCS branch.

Sure, we can write scripts to do this and keep Bamboo plans really dumb. But that mitigates the usefulness of Bamboo. It requires build masters to cherry pick agents for branches, which doesn't scale well; nor is it efficient.  

Here's a scenario I experienced more than once. I took the liberty to assume that Bamboo would support versioning plan configurations in the branch its trying to build. 

h4. Year 1

# A customer reports an issue with release v1.0
# A JIRA issue (DP-123) is created.
# Using JIRA, the developer creates a feature branch (DP-123) from release v1.0
# The developer fixes the issue using Visual Studio 2010 (which is installed on his workstation)
# Developer commits the change
# Bamboo builds the DP-123 branch using a build agent with only Visual Studio 2010 installed.
# The patch is submitted to the customer
# The developer merges DP-123 with release v1.0
# Bamboo builds a new version of release v1.0
# The developer merges DP-123 with master
# Bamboo builds a new version of master
# The developer merges DP-123 with develop
# Bamboo builds a new version of develop

h4. Year 3

# Every developer demands that Visual Studio 2013 and Microsoft.NET 4.5.1 should be used for release v10.
# An JIRA issue is created DP-999 to upgrade the toolset.
# Using JIRA, a developer creates a feature branch DP-999 from master.
# The developer changes the Bamboo plan configuration, versioned with DP-999, to use Visual Studio 2013 and MSBuild 12, rather than Visual Studio 2010 and MSBuild 4. 
# Developer commits the change to branch DP-999.
# Bamboo fails to build branch DP-999 since no agent exists with Visual Studio 2013.  None of the other builds are broken.
# Buildmaster creates a new agent with Visual Studio 2013.
# Bamboo builds branch DP-999 on the new build agent.
# Developer merges DP-999 with the develop branch (assuming the upgrade was seamless)
# Other developers are instructed to install Visual Studio 2013 
# DP-999 is merged with feature branches intended to be part of v10. Older releases are left alone.

Its important to note that while upgrading the toolset, no one else is impacted.  The work of the build master is minimal. It is also possible to abandon the effort without any changes to the plan configuration.  

h4. Year 5

# Customers reports an issue with release v1.0
# A JIRA issue (DP-2563) is created.
# Using JIRA, the developer creates a feature branch (DP-2563) from release v1.0
# The developer fixes the issue using Visual Studio 2010 (which is installed on his workstation)
# Developer commits the change
# Bamboo builds the DP-2563 branch using a build agent with only Visual Studio 2010 installed.
# The developer merges DP-2563 with release v1.0.
# Bamboo builds a new version of release v1.0.
# The release v1.0 patch is submitted to the customer.
# The developer merges DP-2563 with all official releases (if needed)
# Bamboo builds a new version of all official releases (if needed)
# The respective patches are released to customers (if needed).
# The developer merges DP-2563 with develop, addressing any incompatibilities between Visual Studio 2010 and Visual Studio 2013.
# Bamboo builds a new version of develop, using Visual Studio 2013
fields.summary: Versioning Plan Configuration In VCS

fields.description:
Suppose you have an installation where Bamboo, Stash, Confluence and JIRA is integrated.  You have an issue registered in JIRA that says "DP-3" to add some additional functionality.  Bamboo is configured to build the master and develop branches and its configured to automatically detect new branches. 

Using JIRA you initiated the creation of a feature branch, made the changes, waited for  build to pass, tested it and then created a pull request.  That pull request was merged into the "develop" branch and deleted (since its no longer needed). 

However, Bamboo doesn't detect that the branch was deleted and instead reports an error.  

!ScreenShot 2014-07-26 at 21.26.59.png!

For some projects, there is no longer a develop branch listed.

!ScreenShot 2014-07-26 at 21.30.21.png!

In a GIT workflow branches may be short lived and the expectation is that Bamboo will keep up.  Bamboo's error handling should take into account that a branch was deleted and therefore the branch should be archived.  In addition, the absence of a branch doesn't mean there is an error, after all, we told Bamboo to automatically manage branches.  The plans that still exist for deleted branches shouldn't be mixed with active branches.  There could be hundreds of branches being active and even more being inactive for very large teams.

A refresh button may also allow for manual intervention; in essence instruct Bamboo to refresh the branches now, rather than at 3AM.
fields.summary: Provide a means to refresh branches

fields.description:
Currently, there are 2 ways to configure SSH/SCP tasks:
- using password authentication
- using SSH keys, where I _must_ specify the key file.

However, our usecase is different. We manage the SSH keys with puppet and as such we don't need to configure the SSH key in each of the plans.
We would like to use SSH task, but we can't because it requires to select the file key, whereas this is already handled by .ssh/authorized_keys and the default ~/.ssh/id_rsa key that is on the account on which the Bamboo itself is running.

If possible, I would add another option "Custom authentication" with only username and hostname options.
fields.summary: Make SCP and SSH Tasks password field optional

fields.description:
we've some quite important but not urgent deployment scheduled to run at 4 in the morning

we've set this time, as no devs are up and coding, thus we are not delayed by these deployments

moreover, we've our elastic instance set up to shut itself down after some period of inactivity (we definitely don't want to run them all night)

as a result, there is no running instance at 4am when the deployment should happen

unfortunately, Bamboo does not start a new instance, thus our deployments can not run until the morning when we make our first commit, just the time that we wanted to avoid.
fields.summary: Bamboo Deployments should start a new EC instance if there is no instance running

fields.description:
Bamboo currently allows you to configure a MSTest Runner task as documented [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/MSTest+Runner]

Trying to implement from Bamboo Cloud generates the following error:
{noformat}java.lang.IllegalArgumentException : mstest.exe cannot be found{noformat}

However, applying the following [workaround|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/133508/exception-attempting-to-run-mstest-runner-with-mstest-2012?page=1#160403] allows users to utilise the MSTest Runner in the Bamboo Cloud environment:
{quote}So I found a work around solution where you manually call MSTest.exe and then parse the results.

1) Define custom server capability:

{code}Capability Type: Executable
Type: Command
Label: MSTest
Path: C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 11.0\Common7\IDE\MSTest.exe{code}

2) Configure plan test job

3) Add Task > Script (*)
{code}Inline Script Body: IF EXIST %1 DEL %1 
Argument: ${bamboo.buildResultKey}-${bamboo.buildNumber}.trx{code}

4) Add Task > Command
{code}Executable: MSTest
Argument: /testcontainer:[INSERT_YOUR_TEST.DLL] /resultsfile:${bamboo.buildResultKey}-${bamboo.buildNumber}.trx{code}

5) Add Task > MSTest Parser
{code}MSTest Test Results File/Directory: ${bamboo.buildResultKey}-${bamboo.buildNumber}.trx{code}{quote}
fields.summary: Usage of MSTest Runner is not accessible unless implementing a workaround

fields.description:
When

* A branch builds
* and there are changes on master
* and the Branch Updater merges
* and then _pushes the merge on a successful build_

Then

* Any child plans should get triggered with the pushed merge

At the moment, they get triggered with the original merge. This is causing issue when our plan A ensures that everything is compatible, then plan B takes A's artifacts _and_ the wrong repository revision and makes a mess.

(We're using git.)
fields.summary: Child plans don't use merged Branch Updater revision from parent

fields.description:
The artifact download is great and wildly useful. However, one feature that would make it amazing is the option to *build* the copied artifact first. 

OR

Just have an outright task of "Build other Bamboo Plan" and make that block the current plan. 

Currently in Bamboo, you can set up parent/child relationships. This is fine if you don't mind triggering the parent each time, which in turn will trigger the child plan. But what if I just want to click a child plan, and because it depends on a parent, not have to worry that parent gets built first. Currently, there is no way to *force* a parent plan to build no matter what. It would be grand to give the user that option.
fields.summary: Artifact Download task should have option to 'Build Artifact' first.

fields.description: Allow job specific variables (similar to the plan, project, and global variables)

fields.description: Because of BAM-10174, there is no way to create a new plan using the a key that is in the process of being deleted. However, there is no way to see if a specific plan key is being removed since REST reports the plan no longer exists on a query, but you get an error on trying to do a create. Of course, an alternative for REST would be provide an option on the delete request to wait until it is really gone.
fields.summary: Provide REST API that can be used to know whether a plan key is being deleted

When we have test failures in bamboo, only admin users see the testResultActions gear next to the failed test's.

Since I have a team of non-admins that should be reporting these issues, it would be nice if that gear or at least a create issue button existed next to the failure, so anyone on my team can investigate the failure and create the issue in Jira.

fields.description:
Rather than simply controlling ability to launch a task via permissions, I would like to require the user to enter a password to deploy to certain environments (Production specifically.) This would help us with compliance issues as it would provide two factor authentication to deploy to production environments.

One justification for this is that an administrator of bamboo may not necessarilly have permission to deploy to production, but it seems that they are automatically granted full rights.
fields.summary: Add a manual deployment step with a password prompt

fields.description:
This occurs in context of Bamboo Plugins implementing Bamboo Task Plugin Modules.

When a task's {{TaskConfigurator}} or {{RuntimeTaskDataProvider}} implementation uses an injected dependency object, accessing any method on that object after a plugin disable/enable cycle will trigger a ServiceProxyDestroyedException:

{code}
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 2014-07-17 16:54:57,418 ERROR [http-6990-5] [ExceptionMappingInterceptor] service proxy has been destroyed
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.ServiceProxyDestroyedException: service proxy has been destroyed
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceDynamicInterceptor$ServiceLookUpCallback.doWithRetry(ServiceDynamicInterceptor.java:105)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.internal.support.RetryTemplate.execute(RetryTemplate.java:83)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceDynamicInterceptor.lookupService(ServiceDynamicInterceptor.java:430)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceDynamicInterceptor.getTarget(ServiceDynamicInterceptor.java:415)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceInvoker.invoke(ServiceInvoker.java:62)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.doProceed(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:131)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.invoke(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:119)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.util.internal.aop.ServiceTCCLInterceptor.invokeUnprivileged(ServiceTCCLInterceptor.java:56)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.util.internal.aop.ServiceTCCLInterceptor.invoke(ServiceTCCLInterceptor.java:39)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.osgi.service.importer.support.LocalBundleContextAdvice.invoke(LocalBundleContextAdvice.java:59)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.doProceed(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:131)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.invoke(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:119)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy960.getBaseUrl(Unknown Source)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at net.utoolity.atlassian.bamboo.task.ConfigUITaskConfigurator.populateContextForCreate(ConfigUITaskConfigurator.java:44)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.admin.config.task.TaskUIConfigBean.prepareCreateHtml(TaskUIConfigBean.java:109)
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.admin.config.task.CreateTask.input(CreateTask.java:55)
[…]
{code}
(full stacktrace attached as [^ServiceProxyDestroyedException.stacktrace.txt])

(i) The exception is only triggered if the TaskConfigurator or RuntimeTaskDataProvider has been invoked at least once before the disable/enable cycle, hinting on them being instantiated on first use, and not getting updated when the underlying Spring/OSGi context is refreshed.

Reinstalling the plugin fixes the issue (until the next disable/enable cycle).

The problem exists for a single plugin already, but gets worse in a bundled plugin scenario, where updating a dependency plugin triggers a 'background' disable/enable cycle of the dependent plugin, and thus the SPDE problem.

(!) Impact: In the TaskConfigurator scenario, this 'only' prevents the user from creating/configuring tasks all of a sudden, however, for the RuntimeTaskDataProvider scenario, *the impact is a failure of all builds using the affected plugin's tasks!*

To ease analysis and allow testing of potential workarounds, we have created a small [reproduction demo plugin|https://bitbucket.org/utoolity/bamboo-task-spde-reproduction]. (basic reproduction instructions can be found in the project readme file).
fields.summary: ServiceProxyDestroyedException in TaskConfigurator and RuntimeTaskDataProvider after OSGi plugin disable/enable cycle

fields.description:
When I create svn commits like "MYApp-11 This is a bug fix", the next bamboo build does NOT get automatically linked to the JIRA issue because the id is not in ALL CAPS.  If I make a commit with "MYAPP-11 This is a bug is not a feature", then it will be automatically linked.  Since we have some scripts that depend on the auto-linking, I would like Bamboo to be more forgiving if I type a lowercase JIRA id in the commit message.

This is a bug because: (A) it is inconsistent with other plugins like crucible, and the lack of consistent behavior is unexpected and (at first) confusing, and (B) It doesn't handle user "errors", thereby degrading the user experience (it doesn't make things easy and it feels less transparent or automatic).

Please make Bamboo more consistent with other plugins, and let it see JIRA numbers despite how they are capitalized.
fields.summary: Case-insensitive issue number matching.

But the user name needs to be lowercase so I modified to this:

mkdir -p /home/${bamboo.ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName,,}/sites/foo

And I get a "Bad Substitution" error.

fields.description:
Branch expiry is currently based on the last commit date. 

If branch expiry is set to 14 days, and a release branch which hasn't had any work done on it for two weeks is taken from the repo (Though uncommon it can happen when there is a delayed release on some code that isn't very active), the backlogged release that you're trying to do has its builds disappear unexpectedly on the next expiry run.

The workaround to avoid this, is making a commit right away, but having the option to set up expiry based on the latest activity on the branch - in addition to the current workflow which looks at the last commit date - will be very useful.
fields.summary: Ability to set up branch expiry based on the latest activity

Bamboo release process needs to be associated to a plan and this plan needs to have {{green}} builds to allow a release creating.

For this reason, it would be nice to be able to issue a release of the plan on a previous successful build where you would have the option to decide on which build you want to release from.

fields.description:
Bamboo provides support for the following forward proxy parameters:
{code:java}
http.proxyHost
http.proxyPort
https.proxyHost
https.proxyPort
{code}
and not 
{code:java}
http.proxyUser
http.proxyPassword
{code}
for all types of outgoing HTTP requests. This prevents some Bamboo features from working in enterprise settings where forward proxy authentication is enforced for all outgoing requests.

 

*Workaround*
 For interaction with external repository providers that use HTTP/S as the communication protocol (such as bitbucket.org and github.com) a possible workaround is to:
 # Configure the repository entry in the Bamboo Linked repository as type Git (instead of Bitbucket.org or Github).
 # Configure the git client that Bamboo is using as the Git capability to use a forward proxy. For example run the following commands as the same user that runs Bamboo on the Bamboo machine:
{noformat}
$ git config --global http.proxy http://<username>:<password>@<forward_proxy_hostname>:<forward_proxy_port>
$ git config --global http.proxyAuthMethod basic
{noformat}
where you replace the <username>, <password>, <forward_proxy_hostname>, <forward_proxy_port> with the actual values. In the example above the basic authentication is used but you can find more options to configure the forward proxy related parameters at [https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config] The configurations wwould be saved under ~/.gitconfig
# Run your plans.
fields.summary: Add support for the http.proxyUser and http.proxyPassword

Reason: XSRF: A mutative operation was attempted on MutableDeploymentResultImpl within a non-mutative HTTP request: http://10.51.10.97:8085/deploy/stopDeployment.action?deploymentResultId=3244043 : [[null, repair-v2.0-bld101, MutableEnvironmentImpl{position=0, name=DEV-Test}, Unknown, Queued, 2014-07-08 14:59:44.0, 2014-07-08 14:59:44.0, null, null, null, VariableContextBaselineImpl{hash=93eecfc32beb27871a079e00ebe04c70e57114a8}, com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.system.triggerReason:ManualBuildTriggerReason, {ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName=jperaza}]]-> ->[[null, repair-v2.0-bld101, MutableEnvironmentImpl{position=0, name=DEV-Test}, Unknown, NotBuilt, 2014-07-08 14:59:44.0, 2014-07-08 14:59:44.0, null, Tue Jul 08 15:52:49 CDT 2014, null, VariableContextBaselineImpl{hash=93eecfc32beb27871a079e00ebe04c70e57114a8}, com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.system.triggerReason:ManualBuildTriggerReason, {ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName=jperaza}]]

fields.summary: Bamboo sshd should be upgraded to the one that supports key renegotiation

fields.description:
When I select a branch in my (in fact any) Stash repo and save and then edit that branch it has changed to a different branch

See screenshots for examples ...

 * The first screen shot (Correct-Branch-Selected) show me selecting the correct branch before saving.
 * The second screenshot show after I've saved and then edited

This is not just a presentation issue - if I run the build it checks out the WRONG branch - the one I didn't select
fields.summary: Stash branch changes

fields.description:
I'm having a problem where my git checkouts regularly fail causing the build to fail.  This mostly happens to me in the evening/night in the Eastern time zone.

It general takes hours to fail turning a two hour build into a 8-10 hour run that eventually does not work.  The net effect is that our bamboo system has gained a reputation for being an unstable part of the process.

I'm not sure if the issue is bamboo, or if it is bitbucket where our code is hosted.  We currently can't find any evidence that our own  IT resources might be an issue.

I've attached a log of one build step that does the checkout.  Please let me know how I can diagnose and resolve this issue.

Our current installation is version 4.4.4
fields.summary: Git checkouts regularly fail

fields.description:
Current REST API makes it very complicated to get the status of each branch. For creating statusboard widgets, it would be very great to have a simple API providing:

- All known git branches per project (including the project's main branch)
- Their current status (building, failed, testing succeeded etc.)
- Date of last status change
fields.summary: Simple Rest API to provide Branch Status

fields.description:
Please simplify the current log settings UI.

Currently, the user must change log levels for all application subsystems separately.

For debugging Bamboo, it would be helpful to have a switch that just changes the log level of all subsystems at once.
fields.summary: Simplify Log Settings

fields.description:
Since a while, Bamboo only shows a "Page Not Found" error when opening its landing page (e.g. {{http://localhost:8085/}}).

Bamboo is fully functional: E.g. it is possible to login and manage jobs, whith using links like {{http://localhost:8085/userlogin!default.action?os_destination=%2Fadmin%2FconfigureUserManagement.action}}

Switching off application links and plugins doesn't help.

Even if this is a configuration fault: Bamboo should show a more useful error message.
fields.summary: "Page not found" error on landing page

fields.description: Variable definition allows 4000, context allows 255.
fields.summary: Inconsistency between variable length between variable definition and variable context

fields.description:
Bamboo has difficulties to handle very large number of branches for a plan (1k branches).

There should be a soft limit to the number of branches available (and auto detected from the VCS?) to avoid Bamboo to crash when too many branches are being created.

An example would be a problem from the DVCS which results in the creation of many branches (with a really low cost for the DVCS) that would severely impact Bamboo if branch detection is enabled.
fields.summary: Bamboo can't handle (and probably shouldn't) large number of branches per plan

fields.description:
Hi, 
I'm evaluating bamboo and stash. Both reside on the same machine (Intel Xeon 3,4ghz, 16gb RAM). While I'm very satisfied with stash's performance (instant commits and clones via SourceTree), bamboo takes very long for my projects. That is around 4 to 5 minutes for 400mb and lots of files. In comparison to TeamCity, it's very slow.

I've installed it via the installer, I didn't change any configuration.

Any ideas how to speed up things a bit?

fields.summary: Bamboo on Windows git operations very slow (5.5.1 build 4306)

fields.description:
This will be hard to explain...I think...

On the allPlans.acton page. There is a list of plans, each plan has a "Build" column and a "Completed" column, in the Build column there is an icon and the Build Number and a message in the Completed column. Example

[ icon ] #481 1 day ago

When I go to build #482, and it is in progress, the [ icon ] spins/rotates/animates.

OK, this is cool. But the problem is that the [ icon ] is spinning, rotating, animating next to Build #481. This is confusing. It makes it seem like Build #481 is in progress.

It would be better to see the following on the dashboard:

[ icon ] (#482 building) #481 1 day ago

This would remind us that #481 is done and #482 is building. Also, it would make the links consistent to the user experience. When the user clicks on the spinning icon, they are taken to #482. When they click on #481, of course they go to #481 not the in progress build. Having the additional text would allow the user to click on text in addition to the icon to go to the current build in progress.
fields.summary: Build icon on dashboard is confusing

fields.description:
There is currently no document explaining how to file a support ticket and generate a support zip for Bamboo. We need a document similar to the one we have for JIRA: [Getting Help - JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Getting+Help].

We have a page explaining where the logs are located and how they can be modified: [Logging in Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Logging+in+Bamboo], but having the "Getting Help" document is also helpful and necessary.
fields.summary: "Getting Help" document for Bamboo
allow agents to use non-interactive login shell

fields.description: After upgrading bamboo to version 5.5 the code checkout time has increased significantly, i have tried the solution - exchange the existing /webapp/WEB-INF/lib/jna-3.4.0.jar with the attached jna-3.3.0.jar file. but it didn't work for me, In Source Code Checkout i have not checked force clean build option. But still it checks out the whole code whenever a new build is fired and old checked out code directories are deleted. Is there any way with which the could should get updated once it has been checked out so that complete build process takes less time. Or if there is any other way please suggest. Thanks in advance.
fields.summary: Bamboo taking too long to checkout code from SVN after upgrading bamboo to version 5.5

fields.description:
We would like to have the possibility to view on one page, the fail/pass history of all jobs of a plan, which would save us to click on every single build number to get the history of a job. This would be a 2 dimensional table view (jobs of plan VS time/commit)

It would also be really useful to be able to see a similar table of the history of all jobs within a project.
fields.summary: A results view showing all jobs of a plan over time.

fields.description:
Both my Stash and Bamboo instances are authenticated using ActiveDirectory and my application link is configured with 2-legged oauth.

I've been unable to get build status notifications to transmit back to Stash and I the error is the same as https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-13876.

Is there a way to get this configured without using Basic Auth?
fields.summary: Bamboo - Stash build status

fields.description:
Currently if a user is over the 10 job limit with the evaluation license and they switch to starter license they'll be locked out of Bamboo. 

Please add the ability for the user to login and access plan curation options once they've switched to the new license.

Current workaround: Generate a new Eval license from my.atlassian.com, swap in the new license, remove the plans, switch back to the non-eval license.
fields.summary: Allow users over their plan creation limit to login and remove plans

fields.description: Please consider allowing [SauceLabs Bamboo plugin|https://docs.saucelabs.com/ci-integrations/bamboo/] into Bamboo OnDemand. Since SauceLabs is a cloud-based service, it's natural that common customers between Atlassian and SauceLabs would want hosted products, as we do. I've spoken with SauceLabs about this and they said they have already requested this become available for Bamboo OnDemand but said that Atlassian hasn't allowed it yet.
fields.summary: Allow SauceLabs plugin for Bamboo OnDemand

fields.description:
Though the files can be excluded on repo creation a simple flag/checkbox to ignore standard tag regex for polling/triggering would be useful to customers.

Some users have a Bamboo task to automatically create a tag in their repo as part of successful tests, etc. that could cause loops if the build is triggered for the tagging commit.
fields.summary: Add flag to polling to ignore tags

fields.description:
This is the description from the "variables" tab:

{noformat}
For task configuration fields, use the syntax ${bamboo.myvariablename}. For inline scripts, variables are exposed as shell environment variables which can be accessed using the syntax $BAMBOO_MY_VARIABLE_NAME (Linux/Mac OS X) or %BAMBOO_MY_VARIABLE_NAME% (Windows).
{noformat}

It gives the impression that variables will be exposed in the environment with the key uppercased and dots replaced with underscores. Through trial and error, I've found that the underscore replacement happens, but the key is lowercase.

See screenshot - the variable {{test.foo}} can only be accessed via {{$bamboo_test_foo}}, not {{$BAMBOO_TEST_FOO}} as the description implies.

This is really annoying if it causes a step to fail late in a build.
fields.summary: Description on how to use build variables is wrong

fields.description:
Bamboo can create a build that produced an artifact which is then used as part of deployment release. What should happen if you rerun the previously sucessful build - which rebuilds the artefact?   Should the content of the release be implicitly changed or should we detach release from the result.

For example: The DELETE statement conflicted with the REFERENCE constraint "FK2598A6EA3CF8CEA8". The conflict occurred in database "BambooDb", table "dbo.DEPLOYMENT_VERSION_ITEM_BA", column 'ARTIFACT_ID'.
fields.summary: Rerunning a build with deployment artifact

fields.description:
OK, I heard you the first time ;)

!errors.png!
fields.summary: Lots of errors occurred while trying to update the branch view.

fields.description:
Bamboo users sometimes get confused by selecting/deselecting users in the multi-select list of users displayed under {{Bamboo administration >> Security >> Groups}} and editing any group from the list by selecting the {{Edit}} link.

In order to improve usability, it would be interesting replacing multi-select option by checkboxes as per following:
|!bambooGrp.png|thumbnail!|!bambooGrp.suggestion.png|thumbnail!|

The same could be extended to {{Groups}} under {{Bamboo administration >> Security >> Users}} and editing any user from the list by selecting the {{Edit}} list.
fields.summary: Replace multi-select option in Groups by checkboxes

fields.description:
We currently struggle with Quarantines for 2 reasons:

1) Quarantines are inherited from the "master" or main bamboo branch.  If your branch is from a previous release or not quite up to date, your inherited quarantines are likely wrong and you have to wait for at least one failed build to quarantine them.

2) Not all tests fail consistently.  Even if you know a test is flaky, and should be quarantined, you cannot quarantine it until it fails.

Both of these could be helped by allowing manual quarantining of tests whether or not they have ever failed.
fields.summary: Manual Editing of Quarantines List

fields.description:
By default during the running of a build, Bamboo checkouts the repository. Now if the repository is non-existing or disabled, Bamboo tries to do the usual clone and fail.

A good improvement will be not to check the repo for changes if the build is run manually.
fields.summary: Running a manual build should not clone if its repository is disabled or removed

fields.description:
The "rerun failed jobs" action is a great way for people to find that fact that they have flaky tests. For some teams, this is actively harmful.

It'd be good if a plan could have the "rerun failed jobs" action be permanently disabled via a plan config option.
fields.summary: Allow disabling of "rerun failed jobs" in plan config

fields.description:
Currently when selecting a plan to download an artifact from customers do not have a view of the plan branches. It appears that if the branch creates an artifact of the same name as the master (or another branch) the task downloads the most recent artifact.

Customers would like the ability to visually select the specific branch the artifact is pulled from in order to avoid any confusion/mistakes when downloading artifacts.

Currently the dropdown looks like this:
!screenshot.png!

It would be great if each plan could possibly have a further dropdown showing its branches or even just making the plan branches searchable/useable in that list.
fields.summary: Allow customers to visually select a plan branch in the artifact downloader
Bamboo reporting incorrect build log size

fields.description:
h5. Problem

When triggering a build with "Run Customized..." and entering an id from commit that is only available within tags but not in branches the execution fails.

h5. Expected behavior

When triggering a build with "Run Customized..." on a specific commit ID the build should checkout the given ID and should not try to find a related branch.

Or in other words: Using *git branch -a --contains <ID>* should not be used but *git checkout <ID>*.
